utterance: Howdy, marster?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Who are you?
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: I'm name' Joe, marster. I'm Lucindy's ole man.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Who do you belong to?
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: Marse John Evans is my gyardeen, marster.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Big name-gyardeen. Show your pass.
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: To whom it may concern: This is to certify that the boy Joe Frampton has my permission to visit his wife Lucinda.
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: Some mighty big words in that there. Evans owns this place, I reckon. When's he comin' down to take hold?
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: Lucindy say she speck you wouldn't min' my comin', long ez I behave, marster.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Don't want no free niggers 'round here. There's the big road. It'll carry you to town. Don't let me catch you here no more. Now, mind what I tell you.
speaker: Calderwood

utterance: I'uz settin' down front er de fireplace, cookin' me some meat, w'en all of a sudden I year sumpin at de do'-scratch, scratch. I tuck'n tu'n de meat over, en make out I aint year it. Bimeby it come dar 'gin scratch, scratch. I up en open de do', I did, en, bless de Lord! dar wuz little Dan, en it look like ter me dat his ribs done grow tergeer. I gin 'im some bread, en den, w'en he start out, I tuck'n foller 'im, kaze, I say ter myse'f, maybe my nigger man mought be some'rs 'roun'. Dat ar little dog got sense, mon.
speaker: Lucinda

utterance: Miss Becky, whar in de name er gracious you reckon Lucindy is?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Well, the Lord he'p the nigger! Well, the Lord he'p the nigger! haint you been a-seein' her all this blessed time? She's over at old Spite Calderwood's, if she's anywheres, I reckon.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: No'm, dat I aint, Miss Becky. I aint seen Lucindy in now gwine on mighty nigh a mont'.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Well, it haint a-gwine to hurt you. In my day an' time it wuz allers took to be a bad sign when niggers got to honeyin' 'roun' an' gwine on.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: Yessum, dat's so, but me an' my ole 'oman, we 'uz raise tergeer, en dey aint bin many days w'en we 'uz 'way fum one 'n'er like we is now.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Maybe she's up an' took up wi' some un else. You know what the sayin' is, 'New master, new nigger.
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: Dat's so, dat's de sayin', but tain't wid my ole 'oman like 'tis wid yuther niggers. Me en her wuz des natally raise up tergeer. Dey's lots likelier niggers dan w'at I is, but I knows Lucindy mos' good ez I does little Dan dar- dat I does.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Miss Becky, I wish you please, ma'am, take en run yo' kyards en see sump'n n'er 'bout Lucindy; kaze ef she sick, I'm gwine dar. Dey ken take en take me up en gimme a stroppin', but I'm gwine dar.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: I'll turn the cup first, and then I'll run the cards and see what they say.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: I can't tell the day when I've seed the cards run this a-way. What is an' what aint, I'll never tell you; but I know what the cards sez.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: W'at does dey say, Miss Becky?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: They er runnin' quare. These here that I'm a-lookin' at, they stan' for the past. Them there, they er the present; and the t'others, they er the future. Here's a bundle, an' here's a journey as plain as the nose on a man's face. Here's Lucinda
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: Whar she, Miss Becky?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Here she is the queen of spades.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: Well, well, well! Ef dat don't beat my time! De queen er spades! W'en Lucindy year dat hit'll tickle 'er, sho'!
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Here's a bundle an' a journey, and here's Lucinda. An' here's ole Spite Calderwood.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: De Lord he'p my soul! De faver's dar. Yesser, dat's him! W'at de matter 'long wid all un um, Miss Becky?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Here's the journey, here's the big road, here's rivers to cross, here's the bundle to tote.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: They haint no names writ here, an' what it all means I'll never tell you. Cajy, I wish you'd be so good as to han' me my pipe.
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: I håint no hand wi' the kyards, but I reckon I can patch out your misinformation, Becky, bekaze the other day, whiles I was a-finishin' up Mizzers Perdue's rollin'-pin, I hearn a rattlin' in the road. I looked out, an' Spite Calderwood was a-drivin' by in his buggy, an' thar sot Lucinda by him. It'd in-about drapt out er my min'.
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: You aint see um gwine back, is you, Mars Cajy?
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Ef they went back by this road, it must 'a' bin endurin' of the time whiles I was asleep, bekaze I haint bin no furder from my shop than to yon bed.
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: Well, sir!
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Ef it's my beliefs you want, I'll pitch 'em at you fair and free. My beliefs is that Spite Calderwood is gone an' took Lucindy outen the county. Bless your heart and soul! when Spite Calderwood meets the Old Boy in the road they'll be a turrible scuffle. You mark what I tell you.
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: I speck I better be gittin' 'long. Nex' time I see Lucindy, I'm gwine tell 'er w'at Miss Becky say 'bout de queen er spades dat I is. Ef dat don't tickle 'er, dey ain't no nigger 'oman never bin tickle'.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: One minnit ridin' in the buggy 'longside er Mars Spite, en de nex' highfalutin' 'roun' playin' de queen er spades. Mon, deze yer nigger gals gittin' up in de pictur's; dey sholy is.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Good-night, Miss Becky, Mars Cajy
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: Shoo! dem ar dogs is des a-warmin' dat old fox up.
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: You er still layin' off for to strike up wi' Lucindy out thar in the woods, I reckon.
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: "Oh, dey er comin', Mars Cajy, dey er comin', sho," I boun' you dey'll come; en w'en dey does come, I'll des take en fetch um yer, whar you kin see um wid you own eyes, you en Miss Becky."
speaker: Free Joe

utterance: "No," Don't! don't fetch 'em anywheres. Stay right wi' 'em as long as may be."
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: "Look at that nigger; look at 'im. He's pine-blank as happy now as a killdee by a mill-race. You can't 'faze 'em. I'd in-about give up my t'other hand ef I could stan' flat-footed, an' grin at trouble like that there nigger."
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: "'Niggers is niggers," an' you can't rub it out; yit I lay I've seed a heap of white people lots meaner'n Free Joe. He grins, an' that's nigger, but I've ketched his - under jaw a-trimblin' when Lucindy's name uz brung up. An' I tell you, the Old Boy's done sharpened his claws for Spite Calderwood. You'll see, it."
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: "Me, Rebecca?" me? I hope not."
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: "Well, you'll know it then,"
speaker: Becky Staley

utterance: "Git up from there," an' go an' arn your livin'. A mighty purty pass it's come to, when great big buck niggers can lie a-snorin' in the woods all day, when t'other folks is got to be up an' a-gwine. Git up from there!"
speaker: Micajah Staley

utterance: "Rather a lively chap that,"
speaker: the commercial traveller

utterance: "Well, I reckon you won't find no livelier in these diggin's," He's a little chunk of a man, but he's monst'us peart."
speaker: the landlord

utterance: "A colonel, I guess,"
speaker: the commercial traveller

utterance: "Oh, no," He ain't no colonel, but he'd 'a' made a prime one. It's mighty curious to me, that them Yankees up there didn't make him one."
speaker: the landlord

utterance: "The Yankees?"
speaker: the commercial traveller

utterance: "Why, yes," He's a Yankee; and that lady you seen drivin' him around, she's a Yankee. He courted her here and he married her here. Major Jimmy Bass wanted him to marry her in his house, but Capt. Jack Walthall put his foot down and said the weddin' had to be in his house; and there's where it was, in that big white house over yander with the hip roof. Yes, sir."
speaker: the landlord

utterance: "Oh," he staid down here to keep out of the army. He was a lucky fellow."
speaker: the commercial traveller

utterance: "Well, I reckon he was lucky not to get killed," He fought with the Yankees, and they do say that Little Compton was a rattler."
speaker: the landlord

utterance: "If I were you, Pulliam," and wanted to abuse anybody, I'd pick out a bigger man than that."
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "I don't see anybody,"
speaker: Miles Pulliam

utterance: "Well, dyou!" if you are that blind, I'll open your eyes for you!"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Let's call it square, Jack. Your mother and my father are blood cousins, and I don't want any bad feelings to grow out of this racket. I've apologized to Mr. Compton here, and now I'm ready to apologize to you."
speaker: Miles Pulliam

utterance: "Well, by George, Miles Pulliam! if you've apologized to Little Compton, then it's my turn to apologize to you. Maybe I was too quick with my hands, but that chap there is such a d― clever little rascal, that it works me up to see anybody pester him."
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Why, Jack," I'm not such a scrap as you make out. It's just your temper, Jack. Your temper runs clean away with your judgment."
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: "My temper! Why, good Lord, man! don't I just sit right down, and let folks run over me whenever they want to? Would I have done any thing if Miles Pulliam had abused me?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Why, the gilded Queen of Sheba!" only last sale-day you mighty nigh jolted the life out of Bill-Tom Saunders, with the big end of a hickory stick."
speaker: Miles Pulliam

utterance: "That's so," but did I follow him up to do it? Wasn't he dogging after me all day, and strutting around bragging about what he was going to do? Didn't I play the little stray lamb till he rubbed his fist in my face?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "You take all your men," take all un 'em, but gimme Hennery Clay. Them abolishioners, they may come an' git all six er my niggers, if they'll jess but lemme keep the ginny-wine ole Whig docterin'. That's me up an' down - that's wher' your Uncle Abner Lazenberry stan's, boys."
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "Yes, siree! You may jess mark me down that away. 'Come,' sez I, 'an' take all my niggers an' the ole gray mar',' sez I, ‘but lemme keep my Whig docterin',' sez I. Lord, I've seed sights wi' them niggers. They hain't no manner account. They won't work, an' I'm ablidge to feed 'em, else they'd whirl in an' steal from the neighbors. Hit's in-about broke me for to maintain 'em in the'r laziness. Bless your soul, little childern! I'm in a turrible fix - a turrible fix. I'm that bankruptured that when I come to town, ef I fine a thrip in my britches-pocket for to buy me a dram I'm the happiest mortal in the county. Yes, siree! hit's got down to that."
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "What mought be your name, mister?'
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "Oh," my name might be Jones, but it happens to be Davies."
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: "Jesso! Well, dog my cats ef times hain't a-changin' an' a-changin' tell bimeby the natchul world an' all the hummysp'eres 'll make the'r disappearance een'-uppermost. Yit, whiles they er changin' an' a-disappearin', I hope they'll leave me my ole Whig docterin', an' my name, which the fust - an' last un it is Abner Lazenberry. An' more'n that, an' more'n that, they hain't never been a day sence the creation of the world an' the hummysp'eres when my name mought er been any thing else under the shinin' sun but Abner Lazenberry; an' ef the time's done come when any mortal name mought er been any thing but what hit reely is, then we jess better turn the nation an' the federation over to demockeracy an' giner'l damnation. Now that's me, right pine-plank."
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "This is just a saying I've picked up somewhere in my travels. My name is Davies, and I am traveling through the country selling a few choice books, and picking up information as I go."
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: "I know a mighty heap of Davises," but I disremember of anybody name Davies."
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "Well, sir," the name is not uncommon in my part of the country. I am from Vermont."
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: "Well, well!" A mighty fur ways Vermont is, tooby shore. In my day an' time I've seed as many as three men folks from Vermont, an' one un 'em, he wuz a wheelwright, an' one wuz a tin-peddler, an' the yuther one wuz a clock-maker. But that wuz a long time ago. How is the abolishioners gittin' on up that away, an' when in the name er patience is they a-comin' arter my niggers? Lord! if them niggers wuz free, I wouldn't have to slave for 'em."
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: "Well, sir," I take little or no interest in those things. I have to make a humble living, and I leave political questions to the politicians."
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: "What do you know about abolitionists?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Nothin' 'tall, Marse Jack, 'cep'in' w'at dish yer new w'ite man down dar at de tavern say."
speaker: Jake

utterance: "And what did he say?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "I ax 'im, I say, 'Marse Boss, is dese yer bobolitionists got horns en huffs?' en he 'low, he did, dat dey ain't no bobolitionists, kaze dey er babolitionists, an' dey ain't got needer horns ner huffs."
speaker: Jake

utterance: "What else did he say?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Well, sit," dat man des preached. He sholy did. He ax me ef de niggers 'roun' yer would'n all like ter be free, en I tole 'im I don't speck dey would, kase all de free niggers w'at I ever seed is de mos' no-'countes' niggers in de lan'."
speaker: Jake

utterance: You'd be a nice housekeeper, Buck, if you did all your pillows that way
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Why, bless your great big soul, Compy, I'm the finest in the land.
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: Stick her in the back room there, she'll keep.
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: Gentlemen! what is the meaning of this? What would you do?
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: You know mighty well, sir, what we ought to do. We ought to hang you, you imperdent scounderl! A-comin' down here a-pesterin' an' a-meddlin' with t'other people's business.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Why, gentlemen, I'm a peaceable citizen; I trouble nobody. I am simply travelling through the country selling books to those who are able to buy, and giving them away to those who are not.
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: Mr. Davies, what kind of books are you selling?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Religious books, sir.
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: Jake!
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Jake! stand out there. Hold up your head, sir! - Mr. Davies, how many religious books did you sell to that nigger there last night?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I sold him none, sir; I
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: How many did you try to sell him?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I made no attempt to sell him any books; I knew he couldn't read. I merely asked him to give me some information.
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: Jake! do you know this man?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I seed 'im, Marse Jack; I des seed 'im; dat's all I know 'bout 'im.
speaker: Jake

utterance: What were you doing sasshaying around in his room last night?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Jack, hadn't we better take this nigger over to the calaboose?
speaker: Alvin Cozart

utterance: Not yet. If I have to take him over there I'll not bring him back in a hurry.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I wuz des up in his room kaze he tole me fer ter come back en see 'im. Name er God, Marse Jack, w'at ail' you all w'ite folks now?
speaker: Jake

utterance: What did he say to you?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: He ax me w'at make de niggers stay in slave'y, he ax me w'at de reason dey don't git free deyse'f.
speaker: Jake

utterance: He was warm after information.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Call it what you please. I asked him those questions and more.
speaker: Mr. Davies

utterance: Oh, we know that, mister. We know what you come for, and we know what you're goin' away for. We'll excuse you if you'll excuse us, and then there'll be no hard feelin's - that is, not many; none to growl about. — Jake, hand me that bundle there on the barrel, and fetch that tar-bucket. You've got the makin' of a mighty fine bird in you, mister, all you lack's the feathers, and we've got oodles of 'em right here. Now, will you shuck them duds?
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: Why, Jack, what has the man done?
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Well, you heard what the nigger said. We can't afford to have these abolitionists preaching insurrection right in our back yards. We just can't afford it, that's the long and short of it. Maybe you don't understand it; maybe you don't feel as we do; but that's the way the matter stands. We are in a sort of a corner, and we are compelled to protect ourselves.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I don't believe in no tar and feathers for this chap.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: He'll just go out here to the town branch and wash 'em off, and then he'll go on through the plantations raising h— That'll be the upshot of it-now, you mark my words. He ought to be hung.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Now, boys, what is the use? This man hasn't done any real harm. He might preach insurrection around here for a thousand years, and the niggers wouldn't listen to him. Now, you know that yourselves. Turn the poor devil loose, and let him get out of town. Why, haven't you got any confidence in the niggers you've raised yourselves?
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: My dear sir, we've got all the confidence in the world in the niggers, but we can't afford to take any risks. Why, my dear sir, if we let this chap go, it won't be six months before the whole country'll be full of this kind. Look at that Harper's Ferry business.
speaker: Rowan Wornum

utterance: Well, look at it. What harm has been done? Has there been any nigger insurrection?
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Little Compton is a quick talker, boys. Let's give the man the benefit of all the arguments.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Great God! You don't mean to let this d- rascal go, do you, Jack?
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: No, no, sweet uncle; but I've got a nicer dose than tar and feathers.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: By George, boys! this chap could play Old Bob Ridley at the circus.
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: Merciful heavens! is the Ole Boy done gone an' turned hisself loose? I hearn the racket, an' I sez to the ole woman, sez I, 'I'll fling the saddle on the gray mar' an' canter to town an' see what in the dingnation the matter is. An' ef the worl's about to fetch a lurch, I'll git me another dram an' die happy,' sez I. Whar's Jack Walthall? He can tell his Uncle Abner all about it.
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: Well, sir, the State has seceded, and the boys are celebrating.
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: I know'd it. My min' tole me so.
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: Is them rags the things they er gwine to fly out'n the Union with? Why, bless your soul an' body, hit'll take bigger wings than them! Well, sir, I'm sick; I am that away. I wuz born in the Union, an' I'd like mighty well to die thar. Ain't it mine? ain't it our'n? Jess as shore as you're born, thar's trouble ahead-big trouble. You're from the North, ain't you?
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: Yes, sir, I am, that is, I am from New Jersey, but they say New Jersey is out of the Union.
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Well, you better go back where you come from. You ain't got nothin' in the roun' worl' to do with all this hellabaloo. When the pinch comes, as come it must, I'm jes gwine to swap a nigger for a sack er flour an' settle down; but you had better go back where you come from.
speaker: Uncle Abner Lazenberry

utterance: But how?
speaker: Alvin Cozart

utterance: Why, the easiest in the world. Write him a note, and tell him that the time has come for an English-speaking people to take sides, and fling in a kind of side-wiper about New Jersey.
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: Why, stuff, boys! you can't scare Little Compton. He's got grit, and it's the right kind of grit. Why, I'll tell you what's a fact, — the sand in that man's gizzard would make enough mortar to build a fort.
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Well, I'll tell you what we'll do. We'll sling him a line or two, and if it don't stir him up, all right; but if it does, we'll have some tall fun.
speaker: Buck Ransome

utterance: I'm mighty glad you come, —yes, sir, I am. It looks like the whole world's out at the camps, and it makes me feel sorter lonesome. Yes, sir; it does that. If I wasn't so plump I'd be out there too. It's a mighty good place to be about this time of the year. I tell you what, sir, them boys is got the devil in 'em. Yes, sir; there ain't no two ways about that. When they turn themselves loose, somebody or something will git hurt. Now, you mark what I tell you. It's a tough lot, a mighty tough lot. Lord! wouldn't I hate to be a Yankee, and fall in their hands! I'd be glad if I had time for to say my prayers. Yes, sir; I would that.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Oho!
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Jesse, tell Miss Lizzie that Mr. Compton is in the parlor.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: I tell you what, sir, that gal looks mighty puny. She's from the North, and I reckon she's homesick. And then there's all this talk about war. She knows our boys'll eat the Yankees plum up, and I don't blame her for being sorter down-hearted. I wish you'd try to cheer her up. She's a good gal if there ever was one on the face of the earth.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Don't tear yourself away in the heat of the day.
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: I must go.
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Good-by!
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: Good-night, and God bless you!
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: Marse Jack,
speaker: Jake

utterance: Well, what is it?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Marse Jack, I hope ter de Lord you ain't gwine ter git mad wid me; yit I mos' knows you is, kaze I oughter done tole you a long time ago.
speaker: Jake

utterance: You ought to have told me what?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: 'Bout my drivin' yo' hoss en buggy over ter Rockville dat time, dat time what I ain't never tole you 'bout. But I 'uz mos' 'blige' ter do it. I 'low ter myse'f, I did, dat I oughter come tell you right den, but I 'uz skeer'd you mought git mad, en den you wuz out dar at de camps, 'long wid dem milliumterry folks.
speaker: Jake

utterance: What have you got to tell?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Well, Marse Jack, des 'bout takin' yo' hoss en buggy. Marse Compton 'lowed you wouldn't keer, en w'en he say dat, I des went en hitch up de hoss en kyar'd 'im over ter Rockville.
speaker: Jake

utterance: What under heaven did you want to go to Rockville for?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Who? me, Marse Jack? 'Twa'n't me wanter go. Hit 'uz Marse Compton.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Little Compton?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Yes, sir, dat ve'y same man.
speaker: Jake

utterance: What did you carry Little Compton to Rockville for?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Fo' de Lord, Marse Jack, I dunno w'at Marse Compton wanter go fer. I des know'd I 'uz doin' wrong, but he tuck'n 'low' dat hit'd be all right wid you, kaze you bin knowin' him so monst'us well. En den he up'n ax me not to tell you twell he done plum out'n yearin'.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Didn't he say any thing? Didn't he tell you where he was going? Didn't he send any word back?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Well, de Lord he'p my soul! Ef I ain't de beatenest nigger on de top side er de yeth! Marse Compton gun me a letter, en I tuck'n shove it un' de buggy seat, en it's right dar yit ef somebody ain't tored it up.
speaker: Jake

utterance: Come here, sir!
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: Do you stand up there, sir, and tell me all this, and think I am going to put up with it?
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: I'm gwine after dat note, Marse Jack, des ez hard ez ever I kin.
speaker: Jake

utterance: "This is a very unfortunate mistake. What is to be done?"
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "There is no mistake, Mr. Walthall," she replied. "Mr. Compton is a Northern man, and he has gone to join the Northern army. I think he is right."
speaker: Miss Lizzie Fairleigh

utterance: "Well, he will do what he thinks is right, but I wish he was here to-night."
speaker: Capt. Jack Walthall

utterance: "Oh, so do I!"
speaker: Miss Lizzie Fairleigh

utterance: "'If I could get through the lines, I would go home."
speaker: Miss Lizzie Fairleigh

utterance: "Jess! Jess! Oh, Jess!"
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: “Jess,” said the major softly, "I wish you'd please fetch me my shot-gun. Make 'aste, Jess, and don't make no furse."
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Miss Lizzie, did Jack Walthall insult you here in my house?"
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Insult me, sir! Why, he's the noblest gentleman alive."
speaker: Miss Lizzie Fairleigh

utterance: "Well, I'm mighty glad to hear you say so! I couldn't tell, to save my life, what put it into my mind. Why, I might 'a' know'd that Jack Walthall ain't that kind of a chap. Lord! I reckon I must be getting old and weak-minded. Don't cry no more, honey. Go right along and go to bed."
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Oh, go put her up, Jess, go put her up, boy. I wanted to blaze away at a dog out there trying to scratch under the palings; but the dog's done gone. Go put her up, Jess."
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Miss Sa'h, you better keep yo' eye on Marse Maje. He talkin' mighty funny, en he doin' mighty quare."
speaker: Jesse

utterance: "By the livin' Lord! if that ain't Jack Walthall! And you may put out my two eyes if that ain't Little Compton! Why, shucks, boys! I'd 'a' know'd you anywheres. I'm a little short-sighted, and I'm mighty nigh took off wi' the dropsy, but I'd 'a' know'd you anywheres."
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass
addressee: Capt. Jack Walthall and Little Compton

utterance: "Great Jiminy Craminy! don't we all know Little Compton like a book? And ain't he got a right to wear his own duds?'
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "-Boys, when we go, we'll just about lift that feller and take him along. He belongs in Andersonville, that's where he belongs."
speaker: a tall Mississippian

utterance: "I reckon you must 'a' been mighty sick over yander,"
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Well, yes, I've had a pretty tough time."
speaker: a tall Mississippian

utterance: "And you ain't strong yet,"
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Well, I'm able to get about right lively,"
speaker: a tall Mississippian

utterance: "Strong enough to go to war?"
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Oh, well, not - - not just yet."
speaker: a tall Mississippian

utterance: "'Well, then, you better be mighty keerful of yourself in this town. If you ain't strong enough to go to war, you better let Little Compton alone."
speaker: Major Jimmy Bass

utterance: "Marse Compton! Marse Compton! you better run up ter Marse Jack's, kaze one er dem mens is gwine in dar whar ole Miss is, en ef he do dat he gwine ter git hurted!"
speaker: a Walthall negro

utterance: "You musn't think hard of the boys, Jack, on account of that chap. They understand the whole business, and they are going to take care of this town."
speaker: Little Compton

utterance: "-Well, you know this sort of thing doesn't end the war, boys, but I shall sleep better to-night.”
speaker: the Commander
addressee: Capt. Jack Walthall and Little Compton

utterance: "Aunt Harriet, ma says send her some of your nicest preserves."
speaker: a playmate

utterance: "Aunt Harriet, indeed!"
speaker: Harriet Bledsoe

utterance: This is the trouble I was trying to think of,”
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Don't make yourself ridiculous, dear. Serious
matters should be taken seriously.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Aunt Harriet has probably heard me say that there
is still some hope for the country, even though it is
governed entirely by men. The men cannot deprive us of the winter
climate of Boston, and I enjoy that above all things.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
But indeed, Dr. Buxton, the winter climate of Boston, fine as it is,
is beginning to pinch us harder than it used to do.
The air is thinner, and the cold is keener. When I
was younger - very much younger
than I am now,
I remember that I used to run in and out, and fall
and roll in the snow with perfect impunity. But now
I try to profit by Aunt Harriet's example. When I
go out, I go bundled up to the point of suffocation;
and if the wind is from the east, as it usually is, I
wear wraps and shawls indoors.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
You will have to take great care of yourself. You must be prudent. The
slightest change in the temperature may send you
to bed for the rest of the winter.
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance: Dr. Buxton is complimenting you, Aunt Harriet. You should drop him a courtesy.'
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
It is always the way, Dr. Buxton. I believe you would
confess to serious symptoms yourself if Aunt Har-
riet insisted on it. What an extraordinary politician
she would make! My sympathy with the woman-
suffrage movement is in the nature of an investment.
When we women succeed to the control of affairs, I
count on achieving distinction as Aunt Harriet's
niece.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Pray Dr. Buxton, don't humor Aunt Harriet too
much in this. Save your physic for those who are
strong in body and mind. A dozen of your pellets
ought to be a year's supply.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
You must keep Helen indoors until she is a little
stronger, and then
take her to a milder climate.
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance: Oh, not to Florida!
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: Not necessarily.
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance:
Please don't twist your language, Dr. Buxton.
You should say necessarily not.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: And why not to Florida, young lady?
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance:
Ah, I have seen people that came from there. they were too tired to talk much about
the country, but something in their attitude and ap-
pearance seemed to suggest that they had seen the
sea-serpent.
Dear doctor, I have no desire to see
the sea-serpent.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Well, then, my dear child, not to Florida, but to nature's own
sanitarium, the pine woods of Georgia. Yes, nature's
own sanitarium. I tested the piney woods of Georgia
thoroughly years ago. I drifted there in my young
days. I lived there, and taught school there. I grew
strong there, and I have always wanted to go back
there.
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance:
And now, you want to
send Aunt Harriet and poor Me forward as a skir-
mish-line. There is no antidote in your books for
the Ku Klux.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
You will see new scenes and new people. You will get new ideas;
above all, you will breathe the fresh air of heaven
spiced with the odor of pines. It will be the making
of you, my dear child.
speaker: Dr. Buxton

utterance:
Dr. Buxton is a lifelong Democrat. Father
used to tell him he liked his medicine better than
his politics, bitter as some of it was; but in a case
of this kind, Dr. Buxton's politics have a distinct
value. He will give us the grips, the signs, and the
pass-words, dear aunt, and I dare say we shall get
along comfortably.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: Here she is, Marse Peyton,
speaker: a negro boy

utterance:
I declar' ter gracious, Marse Peyton! seem like
I wa'n't never gwine ter git yer. I helt up my
head, I did, fer ter keep my eye on de kyars, en it
look like I run inter all de gullies en on top er all
de stumps 'twix' dis en Marse Tip's.
I des tuk'n
drapt eve'y thing, I did, en tole um dey'd hatter
keep one eye on the dinner-pot, kase I 'blige ter run
en see Marse Peyton off.
speaker: Jincy

utterance:
I boun' you some er deze yer folks 'll go off en
say I'm 'stracted, but I can't he'p dat;
I bleeze ter run down yer ter tell Marse Peyton good-
by. Tell um all howdy fer me, Marse Peyton, all un um. No diffunce ef I ain't know um
all'tain't gwine ter do no harm fer ter tell um dat
ole Jincy say howdy. Hit make me feel right foolish
in de head w'en it come 'cross me dat I use ter tote
Miss Hallie 'roun' w'en she wuz a little bit er baby,
en now she way down dar out'n de worl' mos'. I
wish ter de Lord I uz gwine 'long wid you, Marse
Peyton! Yit I speck, time I got dar, I'd whirl in en
wish myse'f back home.
speaker: Jincy

utterance: God A'mighty bless you, Marse Peyton, honey!
speaker: Jincy

utterance: She called him 'Master,' Helen, did you hear her?
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
I heard her. She called him
Master, and he called her Mammy. It was a very
pleasing exchange of compliments.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: Gener'l Garwood?
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance: Ah! Goolsby! Why, how do you do? Sit down.
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
Well, sir, I can't say my health's any too good.
You look mighty well yourse'f, gener'l. How are
things?
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance: Oh, affairs seem to be improving.
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
Well, now, I ain't so up and down certain about
that, gener'l. Looks like to me that things git wuss and wuss.
I ain't no big man, and I'm ruther disj'inted when
it comes right down to politics; but blame me if it
don't look to me mighty like the whole of creation is
driftin' 'round loose.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
Ah, well, a great
many things are uncomfortable; there is a good deal
of unnecessary irritation growing out of new and
unexpected conditions. But we are getting along
better than we are willing to admit. We are all
fond of grumbling.
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
That's so. But I tell you we're havin'
mighty tough times, gener'l, —mighty tough times.
Yonder's the Yankees on one side, and here's the
blamed niggers on t'other, and betwixt and betweenst
'em a white man's got mighty little chance. And
then, right on top of the whole caboodle, here comes
the panic in the banks, and the epizooty 'mongst the
cattle. I tell you, gener'l, it's tough times, and it's
in-about as much as an honest man can do to pay
hotel bills and have a ticket ready to show up when
the conductor comes along.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
Here I've been runnin' up and down the country
tryin' to sell a book, and I ain't sold a hunderd copies
sence I started,—no, sir, not a hunderd copies.
Maybe you'd like to look at it, gener'l. If I do say it my-
self, it's in-about the best book that a man'll git a
chance to thumb in many a long day.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance: What book is it, Goolsby?
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
It's a book that speaks for itself any day in the
week. it's a history of our own great conflict,
'The Rise and Fall of the Rebellion,' by Schuyler
Paddleford. I don't know what the blamed publish-
ers wanted to put it 'Rebellion' for. I told 'em,
says I, Gentlemen, it'll be up-hill work with this in
the Sunny South. Call it "The Conflict," says I.
But they wouldn't listen, and now I have to work like
a blind nigger splittin' rails. But she's a daisy,
gener❜l, as shore as you're born. She jess reads right
straight along from cover to cover without a bobble.
Why, sir, I never know'd what war was till I mean.
dered through the sample pages of this book. And
they've got your picture in here, gener'l, jest as
natural as life, all for five dollars in cloth, eight
in liberry style, and ten in morocker.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
Now, betwixt you and me, gener'l, I don't nigh like the style of that
book, particular where it rattles up our side. I wa'n't
in the war myself, but blame me if it don't rile me
when I hear outsiders a-cussin' them that was. I
come mighty nigh not takin' holt of it on that ac-
count; but 'twouldn't have done no good, not a bit.
If sech a book is got to be circulated around here, it
better be circulated by some good Southron, a man
that's a kind of antidote to the pizen, as it were. If
I don't sell it, some blamed Yankee'll jump in and
gallop around with it. And I tell you what, gener❜l,
betwixt you and me and the gate-post, it's done come
to that pass where a man can't afford to be too pleg-
gged particular; if he stops for to scratch his head
and consider whether he's a gentleman, some other
feller'll jump in and snatch the rations right out of
his mouth. That's why I'm a-paradin' around tryin'
to sell this book.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
Well, I have no doubt it is a very interesting book.
I have heard of it before. Fetch me a copy when
you come to Azalia again.
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
Maybe you think I ain't a-comin'. Well, sir, you're getting the wrong
measure. I was down in 'Zalia Monday was a week,
and I'm a-goin' down week after next. Fact is,
'Zalia is a
mighty nice place. Gener'l, do you happen to know
Miss Louisa Hornsby? Of course you do! Well,
sir, you might go a week's journey in the wildwood,
as the poet says, and not find a handsomer gal then
that. She's got style from away back.
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
Why, yes! of course I know Miss Lou.
She is a most excellent young lady. And so the
wind sits in that quarter? Your blushes, Goolsby,
are a happy confirmation of many sweet and piquant
rumors.
speaker: Gen. Garwood

utterance:
Oh, come now, gener'l! Oh,
pshaw! Why — oh, go 'way!
speaker: Mr. Goolsby

utterance:
It is worth the trouble of a long journey to behold
such a spectacle.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: He is a coarse, ridiculous creature.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: The affable general, Aunt Harriet?
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: No, child; the other.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Dear aunt, we are in the enemy's country, and
we must ground our prejudices. The book-agent is
pert and crude, but he is not coarse. A coarse man
may be in love, but he would never blush over it.
And as for the affable general-you saw the negro
woman cry over him.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: Poor thing! She sadly needs Instruction.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Ah, yes! that is a theory we should stand to,
but how shall we instruct her to run and cry after
us?
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
My dear child, we want no such disgusting ex-
hibitions. It is enough if we do our duty by these
unfortunates.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
But I do want just such an exhibition, Aunt
Harriet. I should be glad
to have some fortunate or unfortunate creature run
and cry after me.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Well, we are
about to ignore the most impressive fact, after all.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: What is that, Aunt Harriet?
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Why, child, these people are from Azalia, and
for us Azalia is the centre of the universe.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Ah, don't pretend that you are not charmed,
dear aunt. We shall have the pleasure of meeting
the handsome Miss Hornsby, and probably Mr.
Goolsby himself — and certainly the distinguished
general.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
I only hope Ephraim Buxton has a clear con-
science to-day.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Did you observe the attitude of the general
towards Mr. Goolsby, and that of Mr. Goolsby to-
wards the general? The line that the general
drew was visible to the naked eye. But Mr. Gools-
by drew no line. He is friendly and familiar on
principle. I was reminded of the 'Brookline Re-
porter,' which alluded the other day to the London
'Times' as its esteemed contemporary. The affable
general is Mr. Goolsby's esteemed contemporary.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: My dear child, I hope your queer conceits are not the result of your illness.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
No, they are the result of my surroundings. I
have been trying to pretend to myself, ever since we
left Washington, that we are travelling through a
strange country; but it is a mere pretence. I have
been trying to verify some previous impressions of
barbarism and shiftlessness.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Well, upon my word, my dear, I should think you had had ample
opportunity.
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
I have been trying to take the newspaper view, but it is impossible. We must correct the news-
papers, Aunt Harriet, and make ourselves famous.
Every thing I have seen that is not to be traced to
the result of the war belongs to a state of arrested
development.
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Her history must be a pathetic one,"
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Her what, ma'am?"
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "Her history, the story of her life," I dare say it is very touching."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Well, ma'am, Emma Jane Stucky is like one of them there dead pines out there in the clearin'. If you had a stack of almanacs as high as a hoss-rack, you couldn't pick out the year she was young and sappy. She must 'a' started out as a light'd knot, an' she's been a-gittin' tougher year in an' year out, till now she's tougher'n the toughest. No'm, I ain't predijiced agin the poor creetur' - the Lord knows I ain't. If I was, no vittels would she git from me, - not a scrimption."
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "I never saw such an expression on a human countenance. Her eyes will haunt me as long as I live."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Bless your soul and body, child! if you're going to let that poor cree- tur's looks pester you, you'll be worried to death, as certain as the world. There's a hunderd in this settlement jest like her, and ther' must be more'n that, old an' young, 'cause the children look to be as old as the'r grannies. I reckon maybe you ain't used to seein' piney-woods Tackies. Well, ma'am, you wait till you come to know 'em, and if you are in the habits of bein' ha'nted by looks, you'll be the wuss ha'nted mortal in this land, 'less'n it's them that's got the sperrit-rappin's after 'em."
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "Is that you, Bud?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Why, who'd you reckon it wuz, maw? A body'd sorter think, ef they 'uz ter ketch you gwine on that away, that you 'spected ter find some great somebody er nuther a-roostin' in here."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Now, who in the nation did you reckon it wuz, maw?"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Some great somebody,"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Well, the great Jemimy!"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Wher've you been?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Away over yander at the depot, An' I fotch you some May-pops too. I did that! I seed 'em while I wuz a-gwine 'long, an' I sez ter myself, sezee, 'You jess wait thar tell I come 'long back, an' I'll take an' take you ter maw,' sezee."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "I wonder you didn't fergit 'em,"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Who? me! I jess like fer ter see anybody ketch me fergittin' 'em. Now I jess would. I never eat a one, nuther not a one."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "I jess bet a hoss you couldn't guess who I seed; now I jess bet that."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Twer'n't no man, en 'twer'n't no Azalia folks. 'Twuz a gal."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "A gal!"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Yes'n, a gal, an' ef she wa'n't a zooner you may jess take an' knock my chunk out."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Twer'n't no Sal Badger, 'twer'n't no Maria Matthews, 'twer'n't no Lou Hornsby, an' 'twer'n't no Martha Jane Williams, nuther. She wuz a bran'-new gal, an' she went ter the tavern, she did."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "I've done saw 'er,"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "You done saw 'er, maw! Well, the great Jemimy! What's her name, maw?"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "They didn't call no names. They jess sot thar, an' gormandized on waffles an' batter-cakes, an' didn't call no names. Hit made me dribble at the mouf, the way they went on."
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Wuz she purty, maw?"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "I sot an' looked at um, an' I 'lowed maybe the war moughter come betwixt the old un an' her good looks. The t'other one looks mighty slick, but, Lordy! She hain't nigh ez slick ez that ar Lou Hornsby; yit she's got lots purtier motions."
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "'Well, I seed 'er, maw,' Atter the ingine come a-snortin' by, I jumped up behind the hack whar they puts the trunks, an' I got a right good glimp' un 'er; an' ef she hain't purty, then I dunner what purty is. What'd you say her name wuz, maw?"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Lordy, jess hark ter the creetur! Hain't I jess this minute hollered, an' tole you that they hain't called no names?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "I 'lowed maybe you moughter hearn the name named, an' then drapt it. I tell you what, she made that ole hack look big, she did!"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "You talk like you er start crazy, Bud! Lordy! what's she by the side er me? Is she made out'n i'on?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "No'm-no'm; that she hain't made out'n i'on! She's lots littler'n you is - lots littler. She looks like she's sorry.'"
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Sorry! What fer?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "Sorry fer we-all."
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: "Sorry fer we-all, honey, when we er got this great big pile er tavern vittles?"
speaker: Emma Jane Stucky

utterance: "I wonder, if these people really regard us as enemies?"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Pray, what difference does it make?"
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Oh, none at all! I was just thinking. The little preacher was tremendously gay. His mind seemed to be on skates. He touched on every subject but the war, and that he glided around gracefully. No doubt they have had enough of war down here."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "I should hope so. Go to sleep, child: you need rest."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "What did you say your name is?"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "I'm name' Willum, ma'm, en my mammy she name' Sa'er Jane, en de baby she name' Philly-peener. Miss 'Ria she say dat baby is de likelies' nigger baby w'at she y'ever been see sence de war, en I speck she is, kaze Miss 'Ria ain't been talk dat away 'bout eve'y nigger baby w'at come 'long."
speaker: William

utterance: "How old are you?"
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "I dunno'm. Miss 'Ria she says I'm lots older dan w'at I looks ter be, en I speck dat's so, kaze mammy say dey got ter be a runt 'mongst all folks's famblies."
speaker: William

utterance: "Mammy say ole Miss gwine come see you all. Mars Peyt gwine bring 'er."
speaker: William

utterance: "Who is old Miss?"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Dunner who ole Miss is? Lordy! you de fus' folks w'at ain't know ole Miss. She Mars Peyt's own mammy, dat's who she is, en ef she come lak dey say she comin', hit'll be de fus' time she y'ever sot foot in dish yer tavern less'n 'twuz indurance er de war. Miss 'Ria say she wish ter goodness ole Miss 'ud sen' word ef she gwine stay ter dinner so she kin fix up somepin n'er nice. I dunno whe'er Miss Hallie comin' er no, but ole Miss comin', sho, kaze I done been year um sesso."
speaker: William

utterance: "And who is Miss Hallie?"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Miss Hallie-she-dunno'm, ceppin' she des stays dar 'long wid um. Miss 'Ria say she mighty quare, but I wish turrer folks wuz quare lak Miss Hallie."
speaker: William

utterance: "Such an event seems to be very interesting,"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Yes'm, it ruther took me back when I heard the niggers talkin' about it this mornin'. If that old lady has ever darkened my door, I've done forgot it. She's mighty nice and neighborly, but she don't go out much. Oh, she's nice and proud; Lord, if pride 'ud kill a body, that old 'oman would 'a' been dead too long ago to talk about. They're all proud - the whole kit and b'ilin'. She mayn't be too proud to come to this here tavern, but I know she ain't never been here. The preacher used to say that pride drives out grace, but I don't believe it, because that 'ud strip the Garwoods of all they've got in this world; and I know they're just as good as they can be."
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "I heard the little negro boy talking of Miss Hallie. Pray, who is she?"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "The poor child! I declare, I feel like cryin' every time I think about her. She's the forlornest poor creetur the Lord ever let live, and one of the best. Sometimes, when I git tore up in my mind, and begin to think that every thing's wrong-end foremost, I jess think of Hallie Garwood, and then I don't have no more trouble."
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "The poor child was a Herndon; I reckon you've heard tell of the Virginia Herndons. At the begin- ning of the war, she was married to Ethel Garwood; and, bless your life, she hadn't been married more'n a week before Ethel was killed. 'Twa'n't in no bat- tle, but jess in a kind of skirmish. They fotch him home, and Hallie come along with him, and right here she's been ev'ry sence. She does mighty quare. She don't wear nothin' but black, and she don't go nowhere less'n it's somewheres where there's sick- ness. It makes my blood run cold to think about that poor creetur. Trouble hits some folks and glances off, and it hits some and thar it sticks. I tell you what, them that it gives the go-by ought to be monst'ous proud."
speaker: Mrs. Haley

utterance: "I am so pleased to meet you. And this is Miss Tewksbury. Really, I have heard my son speak of you so often that I seem to know you. This is my daughter Hallie. She doesn't go out often, but she insisted on coming with me to-day."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "I'm very glad you came,"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "I think you are lovely,"
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "I lovely? I have never been accused of such a thing before."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "You have such a beautiful complexion. I had heard some one had told me that you were an invalid. I was so sorry."
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "My invalidism is a myth. It is the invention of my aunt and our family physician. They have a theory that my lungs are affected, and that the air of the pine-woods will do me good."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Oh, I hope and trust it will! You are so young- so full of life."
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "My dear child, I am older than you are, ever so much older."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Oh, impossible! How could that be? I was sixteen in 1862."
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "Then, you are twenty-seven, and I am twenty-five."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "I knew it, I felt it!"
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "Ephraim Buxton! Why, you don't tell me that Ephraim Buxton is practising medicine in Boston? And do you really know him? Why, Ephraim Buxton was my first sweetheart!"
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "It was quite romantic. Ephraim was the school-teacher here, and I was his eldest scholar. He was young and green and awkward, but the best-hearted, the most generous mortal I ever saw. I made quite a hero of him."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "Well, I have never seen any thing very heroic about Dr. Buxton. He comes and goes, and pre- scribes his pills, like all other doctors."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Ah, that was forty years ago. A hero can become very commonplace in forty years. Dr. Buxton must be a dear good man. Is he married?"
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "No. He has been wise in his day and generation."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "What a pity! He would have made some woman happy."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "My son has been telling me of some of the little controversies he had with you. He says you fairly bristle with arguments."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "The general never heard half my arguments. He never gave me an opportunity to use them."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "My son is very conservative. After the war he felt the responsibility of his position. A great many people looked up to him. For a long time after the surrender we had no law and no courts, and there was a great deal of confusion. Oh, you can't imagine! Every man was his own judge and jury."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "So I've been told."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Of course you know something about it, but you can have no conception of the real condition of things. It was a tremendous upheaval coming after a terrible struggle, and my son felt that some one should set an example of prudence. His theory was, and is, that every thing was for the best, and that our people should make the best of it. I think he was right, but I don't know."
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance: "Why, unquestionably!"
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "Did you lose any one in the war?"
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "I lost a darling brother,"
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Dear heart! you must come and see me. We will talk together. I love those who are sorrowful."
speaker: Hallie

utterance: "Aunt Harriet, what do you make of these people? Did you see that poor girl, and hear her talk? She chilled me and entranced me."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: "Don't talk so, child; they are very good people, much better people than I thought we should find in this wilderness. It is a comfort to talk to them."
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance: "But that poor girl. She is a mystery to me. She reminds me of a figure I have seen on the stage, or read about in some old book."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: 'Daddy! O Daddy! I'm gwine on de skirmish line. I speck we gwine ter have some fun out dar.'
speaker: my young marster

utterance: 'Honey, you make 'aste back ter break'us, kaze I got some sossige meat en some gennywine coffee."
speaker: Uncle Prince

utterance: Good-night, Daddy.'
speaker: my young marster

It is a pity," said Helen, "that his identity
should be so utterly lost."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Hallie, my dear," said Mrs. Garwood, "would it
trouble you too much to get the photograph of the
Union soldier? If it is any trouble, my child
speaker: Mrs. Garwood

utterance:
The face is an interesting one, as well as I can
make out," said Helen, "and it has a strangely
familiar look. He was very young."
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: I can't see by this light,'

utterance:
Why, my dear," said Miss Tewksbury, in a tone of voice that suggested both
awe and consternation, "why, my dear, this is
your brother Wendell!'
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Oh, aunt Harriet! I thought so I was afraid
so-but are you sure?'
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance: As sure as that I am sitting here.'
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

utterance:
Oh, why didn't I recog-
nize him? How could I fail to know my darling
brother?'
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
I knew it! I knew it! I knew that some poor
heart would find its long-lost treasure here. I have
felt it I have dreamed it! Oh, I am so glad you
have found your brother!'
speaker: Hallie

utterance: Oh, but I should have known his picture,'
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
But, my dear child,' said Miss Tewksbury, in a
matter-of-fact way, "there is every reason why you
should not have known it. This picture was taken
in Washington, and he never sent a copy of it home.
If he did, your father put it away among his papers.
You were not more than twelve years old when
Wendell went away.'
speaker: Miss Tewksbury

Perhaps if Hallie will get the fragment of let-
ter,'

but I
got two eyes, en dey er good ones. W'at I sees

speaker: Uncle Prince

utterance: Done got strucken 'bout what?'
speaker: 'Mandy Jane

Bout dat young lady w'at stayin' yer. Oh, you
neenter holler,'

utterance:
I ain't
nothin' but a nigger man, but I knows w'at I sees.'
speaker: Uncle Prince

utterance: Yes, you is a nigger man,'
speaker: 'Mandy Jane

utterance:
Ef you wuz a nigger 'oman you'd have

dar ain't our folks. She mighty nice, I speck, but
she ain't our folks. She ain't talk like our folks yit.'
speaker: 'Mandy Jane

utterance: No matter 'bout dat,'

utterance:
I ain't
seed no nicer 'oman dan w'at she is, en I boun' you

Marse Peyton done got strucken long wid dat white

speaker: Uncle Prince

utterance: En now you gwine tell me,'

dat Marse Peyton
gwine marry wid dat w'ite 'oman en trapse off dar

speaker: 'Mandy Jane

utterance:
I dunno whar Marse Peyton gwine, 'Mandy Jane,
but I done see 'im talkin' 'long wid dat white lady, en
lookin' at her wid he's eyes. Huh! don' tell me!

En dat ain't all, 'Mandy Jane,'

dat Bud Stucky, he's f'rever'n etarnally sneakin'

dat ar white lady fum de Norf.'

got a mammy, en my min' tell me dat he's mammy
kin run de kyards en trick you. Now you watch

I'm all ready, an'

speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: Oh, what can I do?'
speaker: Helen Eustis

utterance:
Please, ma'am, make 'er let me go. I been a-layin'
here ready two whole days an' three long nights, but
maw keeps on a-watchin' of me; she won't let me
go. She's got 'er eyes nailed on me constant.'
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance:
Won't you please, ma'am, tell maw to let me go?
I'm so tired er waitin'.'
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance:
Oh, I'm so tired! I'm all ready, an' she won't
let me go. A long time ago when I us' ter ax 'er,
she'd let me do 'most any thing, an' now she won't
let me go. Oh, Lordy! I'm so tired er waitin'!
Please, ma'am, ax 'er to let me go.'
speaker: Bud Stucky

utterance: Whatter you cryin' fer now?'

utterance:
You wouldn't a-wiped your
feet on 'im. Ef you wuz gwine ter cry, whyn't you
let 'im see you do it 'fore he died? What good do it
do 'im now? He wa'n't made out'n i'on like me.'
